raw_text:
MPs quiz aides over royal income
 
 Senior officials at the two bodies generating private income for the Queen and Prince of Wales are to be questioned by MPs.
 
 Aides from the Duchy of Lancaster and Duchy of Cornwall will appear before the Commons Public Accounts Committee. It has been reported they could be questioned about Prince Charles' spending on Camilla Parker Bowles. But BBC correspondent Peter Hunt said they are not responsible for how money is spent and may be unable to answer. Duchy officials, who will appear before the committee on Monday, are only responsible for generating money. The Duchy of Lancaster provides the Queen's private income, while the Duchy of Cornwall provides Prince Charles' annual income. The Duchy of Cornwall is a 140,000-acre estate across 25 counties, and also includes residential properties, shops, offices, stocks and shares. It was set up in 1337 by King Edward III to provide income for successive heirs to the throne. It covers the cost of the prince's public and private life - neither Charles, nor William and Harry, receive taxpayers' money from the Civil List. However, the Prince of Wales did receive over £4m from government departments and grants-in-aid in 2003-4. The duchy last year generated almost £12m. The prince has voluntarily paid income tax - currently 40% - since 1993.

He receives no taxpayer funding from the Civil List.

However, the duchies are responsible only for generating income and may not be able to fully answer questions. The Duchy of Cornwall provides annual income for Prince Charles, including income from an estate covering 140,000 acres in 25 counties, residential properties, shops, offices, stocks and shares. While the prince doesn't receive taxpayers' money from the Civil List, he did receive over £4m from government departments and grants-in-aid in 2003-4. Last year, the Duchy generated almost £12m. Charles has voluntarily paid income tax since 1993 at a rate of 40%.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about MPs quiz aides questioning officials related to royal income. Let me read through it carefully.

First paragraph: MPs are assigning quiz aides to investigate income generated by UK MPs for the Queen and Prince of Wales. The senior officials from both bodies will be questioned by MPs. Interesting angle on public-private splitting, maybe targeting some reforms or something?

Second paragraph: They mention a specific group from the Duchy of Cornwall being questioned. Specifically about Peter Hunt saying they aren't responsible for how money is spent, maybe? But some of them are accountable for generating income. That makes sense because the Duchy deals with their own taxes and affairs.

Third part: The Duchy of Lancaster provides income to the Queen, while the Duchy of Cornwall provides income to Prince Charles each year. Their property details are provided—140,000 acres in 25 counties, including stuff like residential homes, shops, offices, stocks, and shares. This sounds like a big estate that's been around for over a thousand years.

Fourth paragraph: The Duchy of Cornwall was set up by King Edward III to provide income for the next king (Charles II) after his death. They're responsible for taxes from the government and grants-in-aid in 2003-4, so they definitely handle money flow properly. They made over £12 million last year.

Fifth paragraph: The Prince of Wales has paid income tax since 1993 at 40%. That's a significant figure; maybe he's trying to show that the system is working or needs reforming? He also received money from various sources, which isn't directly related to public-private splitting but shows his financial stability.

Putting it all together, I need to highlight the main points: MPs are questioning officials for income generation related to royal taxes, a specific group in Cornwall will be questioned, their responsibilities and how they manage finances. Also, some responsible, others not so much, given public interest issues.
</think>

 MPs are assigning quiz aides to investigate income generated by UK MPs for the Queen and Prince of Wales, generating private income for them. Aides from the Duchy of Lancaster (Queen) and Duchy of Cornwall (Prince Charles) will be questioned before the Commons Public Accounts Committee. The Duchy of Cornwall is responsible for generating Prince Charles' income annually, providing a 140,000-acre estate across 25 counties with residential properties, shops, offices, stocks, shares, and public expenses. They were set up by King Edward III to fund successive monarchs' taxes since 1337. The Duchy generated over £12 million last year. The Prince of Wales has paid income tax at 40% from 1993 to the present.
